caption: This museum is located in painter Eug√®ne Delacroix's last apartment; he moved to this location on December 28, 1857, and remained until his death on August 13, 1863. It is both his home and studio.  Rotating exhibits but the museum displays a lot of his work and even has one of his pallettes and some brushes. The garden in back is wonderful. Very quiet and restful. Chairs and benches are all around and it is a great spot for sitting and contemplating.  There is a wonderful huge fig tree that has figs in season. Probably not there in Delacroix's time but nice to imagine it was.  A great way to learn more about this important artist.

Small, intimate and personal without the giant crowds of the Louvre. Well worth the visit. Tucked in the heart of the 6th, there are lots of places to explore after seeing the museum. There are stairs to navigate and on this day the elevator was not working, but the website stated the elevator was out of service, so you can check in advance.
A very peaceful and subtle museum to visit, located in the apartment of the artist and has a very nice garden attached to it!

4.1. Delacroix is best known for a single painting, Liberty Leading the People. It was an inspiration for Berthold‚Äôs Statue of Liberty. This museum is set in his former apartment/studio and features only a few dozen little known works from this artist. It was a nice break from walking the shops.

The Mus√©e national Eug√®ne-Delacroix is a small but captivating museum dedicated to the life and work of the famous French Romantic painter, Eug√®ne Delacroix. Located in his former apartment and studio in the heart of Paris, the museum offers a unique, intimate glimpse into his creative process. The collection includes some of Delacroix‚Äôs key paintings, sketches, and personal belongings. The peaceful garden surrounding the museum adds to the charm, making it a wonderful, off-the-beaten-path spot for art lovers looking to explore Delacroix‚Äôs legacy.
Free to visit with museum pass. Small, lovely museum. Sit in its garden and relax, paint the flowers grass etc. Must see while passingby.
Small museum with cozy beautiful garden. I had good time thinking about many things in the garden.

Worth a visit. Especially since it is free of charge. Not too small, not too big. The exhibition spaces are various and fit for purpose. The present exhibition (summer 2024) is about Ingres and Delacroix, their personalities and differences. Interesting and well presented also in English. Eug√®ne Delacroix (born 1798) lived in this apartment from 1857 until his death, 1863.

It‚Äôs a small museum sitting in a quiet corner. There are some sketches and a few paintings, including a sketch of the famous Liberty Leading People which was shown at Louvre. Other than that, not too much to see. The backyard garden is really nice though. I got free entry with the Museum Pass.

Really enjoy the artwork of Delacroix, and was curious to see where he lived. It is a nice place with very little of the furniture. Lots of empty rooms with some of his sketches and a few paintings. His collection on the Louvre is amazing.

I truly enjoyed this simple museum that gives a glimpse into the artistic and home life of Eug√®ne Delacroix. Many of his best works are elsewhere, but if you are intrigued by his love of theatre and music and its influence on his art, this is a lovely museum to gain perspective.

The museum where the great painter Delacroix lived. Can be a little bit disappointing because it‚Äôs quite small(3 rooms, 1 atelier and small garden) and doesn‚Äôt have many masterpieces there. There are some sketches of paintings and his portraits only. And because it‚Äôs not big enough to accommodate many visitors, it maybe hard to reserve the ticket during tourist peak season. Nevertheless, I strongly recommend to give a visit. And If you have a ticket of the Louvre museum, you don‚Äôt have to pay the ticket of this museum on the visit day of Louvre and the next day. But still, you need to reserve the visit time.

Up close look at the life of the grand painter best known for "Liberty leading the people." His paint palettes are here and he has a beautiful garden!! Restroom on site We went the day after seeing the louvre for free entry (you can get in the same day or next day of a louvre ticket).

A great lesser known museum on a super romantic square. After visiting the museum, it's fun to go on a "scavenger hunt" around town viewing works by Delacroix scattered throughout churches and museums.

Nice little place mostly dedicated to artist's work. Little garden is absolutely quiet in the middle of rush hour. Enter for free with the same day Louvre tickets. Unless you are a real Delacruix connoisseur it won't take much time to visit. Almost nothing in English.

We enjoy small museums and this one fits the bill. However, as much as I enjoyed the paintings, etchings and watercolors, I would like to have seen how his art studio and house looked like when he lived there in mid 19th century. Like the museums of Monet‚Äôs house snd Cezanne‚Äôs studio. Still worth a visit if you are interested in this key painter who influenced ‚Äúmodern‚Äù art.

Small museum and safe space to be calm in the middle of huge Paris.  It‚Äôs a small museum that has a garden in the back that it‚Äôs so peaceful that it‚Äôs so cool just to go to relax a while.  It has some paintings of Eug√®ne Delacroix and they‚Äôre so cool! It‚Äôs a museum like part of the Louvre, so for under 26 it‚Äôs free!  Don‚Äôt forget to see the studio in the back! ‚ò∫Ô∏è
Although small, it has the proper vibes of the Master who inhabited this place for the last years of his life.
Beautiful museum but small, with some paintings. It was his house and atelier.
Small museum (1hour max) in the house and workshop of the artist. A few paintings and drawings, and temporary exhibition in autumn.

A great small museum which is really worth a visit. It's situated in a old building complex with a fine permanent exhibition in the main house and some changing exhibitions in the former atelier, situated in a nice and lovely garden which was restyled from the chief gardener from the Tuileries garden in 2012. The entrance is free if you have a entrance ticket from the Louvre museum from the same day.
This was a beautiful little museum. Intimate and very informative about the life of the artist. The only issue I had was finding it. The main door actually looks like a garage entrance.

It is more of a small museum than his house and workshop.  I was expecting more furniture and more of a workshop. They had some cool things painting box‚Äôs and the history about the house was nice. Few nice pieces of art some things were in English and Spanish.
Don't expect to see any master pieces of Delacroix, there are mainly sketches of the artist in four small rooms.
Love the tranquillity here. It‚Äôs a shame that not many works to see. Staffs are kind and helpful.
A small museum with a lovely garden ü™¥

This small gallery / museum offers a great insight into the life and works of Eugene Delacroix and tells his story succinctly without getting too mired in the details of his relationships or the art movements he was involved in. There are 4 adjoining rooms in the first section, one containing a small gift shop. The 2nd room, the saloon, is down a flight of stairs and also connects to the garden. You can get round the whole place in less than an hour (while still reading all the plaques) which makes it ideal as a bite sized culture excursion.  You can also get free entry on the first Sunday of the month.
Interesting place. Nice to think that Delacroix painted in this atelier.

Small place with small number of paintings.. ticket price could be cheaper. Even though Delacroix is one of my favourite artists I'm not sure if this place is worth the price. Staffs were welcoming and helping.
A stone's throw from Saint-Germain-des-Pr√©s church, a little jewel box museum with a very pleasant garden.
I‚Äôm not an expert in art. This is a smaller museum. Best part was free admission within 48 hours of visiting the Louvre.
A small museum with some Delacroix works. Good to see his studio and garden. 30 mins were enough to go through everything.
Totally absurd rules: they basically harrass you throughout. This could be a nice little museum, but the administration turned it into one of the most distasteful in the world.
Beautiful small museum including Delacroix‚Äôs studio and delightful garden. The exhibition on Ingres and Delacroix was very well curated.

Museum is ok, interesting to be in the home of Delacroix.  Staffed by several bored looking people. I emailed the museum with a couple of questions but didn't get a response. On the whole an underwhelming experience. Wouldn't bother next time.

A part from the beautiful art and Eugene‚Äôs representation of mythology and classical stories in the paintings, it is a very calm and beautiful place not only because of the garden but also because of the neighbourhood. And it‚Äôs free for under 26 year old‚Äôs.
Free each 1st Sunday of the month. Reservation needed.

For the people who visit Louvre Museum, they have free access to this Museum within 48 hours from the first use of Louvre museum ticket. Unfortunately eventhough I already had a ticket for it, but it didn't even worth going there (I regret spending 2 hours on the way to it)
